fields.helpText: N.B. Month goes first! This the date that the News item was originally published
This is the news or media outlet that news item appears on
This field should be filled when there either a single related programme or multiple related programmes
Select an 'innovation' to connect to a News item

This summary should provide essential information on the related programme and people as well as providing links to their relevant pages. It should, when possible, include a solid quote from the article. This portion should precede the 'Excerpt' section.
This should be the first three (3) paragraphs from the article OR the first part that you are able to copy and paste from anything that is behind a paywall.

messages.pattern: Must be alphanumerical and not contain any spaces or special characters

summary:
Il Mattino reviews Maestro Andrea Bocelli’s concert in the Pompeii amphitheatre, describing the evening as a “triumph” and a “huge success.”

Among the cast of singers and musicians invited to perform alongside the Maestro were two Bocelli-Jameel scholars: Clara Barbier Serrano (2020) and Laura Mekhail (2021).

Il Mattino writes: “Serena Gamberoni, Clara Barbier Serrano, Aigerim Altynbek and Laura Mekhail are the four sopranos called upon to offer a crucial interlocution to the evening's undisputed star.”

The African Union estimates that 485 million people on the continent are directly affected by land degradation, with droughts accounting for over 44% of all global drought-related disasters.

Tahira Mohamed, a research fellow at the Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action, told CGTN Africa that while climate change is the primary driver for droughts, a critical gap remains in disaster preparedness:

“What we need is goodwill from the government, embedding the anticipatory action planning for drought management and also financing, because if you don't finance then the early warnings will not be useful.”

‍

In an op-ed for Le Monde, Esther Duflo (J-PAL) argues that development aid is not a waste of public money, highlighting the progress of poor countries in recent decades and the role of foreign aid in proving innovative, successful development strategies.

Esther writes: “The credit for this goes primarily to the governments and people of these countries.

“But development aid from rich countries has also played an important role in strengthening global public goods, overcoming crises and rigorously testing and evaluating innovative approaches.”

Reuters features the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo in a report on the school’s revival of Egyptian heritage crafts.

Highlighting how the programme is reinvigorating traditional arts for a new generation, Reuters interviewed Mamdouh Sakr, programme director of the Jameel House in Cairo, who explained:

“There are over 200 graduates from the Jameel House, and our goal from the beginning, we had several goals: to preserve the heritage and traditional crafts, to train people on them and teach them, and at the same time to be able to tackle traditional and heritage crafts in a somewhat contemporary way.”

Al-Arab highlights the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo for its revival of heritage crafts in Egypt.

Focusing on the programme’s human impact, the article looks at how the Jameel House in Cairo provides opportunities to women who face difficulties learning traditional arts.

Noha El-Qahwagy, head of the Jameel House in Cairo’s copper and metals department, explains: “Copper is an authentic material that has always been associated with our homes.

“I had been trying to find a way to learn this craft since school, but most workshops refused to train women. I searched for a long time until I found the right environment at the Jameel House.”

Speaking The Washington Post, Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee (J-PAL) point to evidence that, over the last 25 years, aid has improved living standards for the world’s poorest faster than expected.

Professor Duflo says: “There has been a tremendous amount of progress, often without much outside money.”

RED NOSES announces a new collabration with the Jameel Arts and Health Lab and the World Health Organisation regional office for Europe to explore the impact of healthcare clowning in Lesvos, Greece, from 2025-2027.

A pioneering research study will evaluate the effectiveness of the clowns’ artistic interventions on the wellbeing and social connectedness of unaccompanied minors and aid workers supporting forced migrants.

Lesvos has experienced a surge in refugees since 2024, with studies showing that up to 87% of refugees experience anxiety, depression and related symptoms.

Alongside the pressure and stress placed on aid workers, this demonstrates the need for enhanced psychosocial support that the collaboration hopes to provide.

SUGGESTIONS OR FEEDBACK? HOW J-WAFS SOLUTIONS GRANTS BRING RESEARCH TO MARKET

For the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS), 2025 marks a decade of translating groundbreaking research into tangible solutions for global challenges. Few examples illustrate that mission better than NONA Technologies. With support from a J-WAFS Solutions grant, MIT electrical engineering and biological engineering Professor Jongyoon Han and his team developed a portable desalination device that transforms seawater into clean drinking water without filters or high-pressure pumps. The device stands apart from traditional systems because conventional desalination technologies, like reverse osmosis, are energy-intensive, prone to fouling, and typically deployed at large, centralized plants. In contrast, the device developed in Han's lab employs ion concentration polarization technology to remove salts and particles from seawater, producing potable water that exceeds World Health Organization standards. It is compact, solar-powered, and operable at the push of a button - making it an ideal solution for off-grid and disaster-stricken areas.

This research laid the foundation for spinning out NONA Technologies along with co-founders Junghyo Yoon, a former postdoc in Han's lab, and Bruce Crawford MBA '23, to commercialize the technology and address pressing water-scarcity issues worldwide. "This is really the culmination of a 10-year journey that I and my group have been on," said Han in an earlier MIT News article. "We worked for years on the physics behind individual desalination processes, but pushing all those advances into a box, building a system, and demonstrating it in the ocean ... that was a really meaningful and rewarding experience for me." You can watch this video showcasing the device in action.

Moving breakthrough research out of the lab and into the world is a well-known challenge. While traditional "seed" grants typically support early-stage research at Technology Readiness Level (TRL) 1-2, few funding sources exist to help academic teams navigate to the next phase of technology development. The J-WAFS Solutions Program is strategically designed to address this critical gap by supporting technologies in the high-risk, early-commercialization phase that is often neglected by traditional research, corporate, and venture funding. By supporting technologies at TRLs 3-5, the program increases the likelihood that promising innovations will survive beyond the university setting, advancing sufficiently to attract follow-on funding. Equally important, the program gives academic researchers the time, resources, and flexibility to de-risk their technology, explore customer need and potential real-world applications, and determine whether and how they want to pursue commercialization.

For faculty-led teams like Han's, the J-WAFS Solutions Program provided the critical financial runway and entrepreneurial guidance needed to refine the technology, test assumptions about market fit, and lay the foundation for a startup team. While still in the MIT innovation ecosystem, NONA secured over £200

Arts for Health in the Face of Climate Change: Community Jameel x Afikra COP28 Conversations – Episode 2 

In this live session of the Community Jameel x Afikra COP28 Conversation Series at Jameel Arts Centre, panelists working at the intersection of the arts, health, and climate action explored the important role of art and arts organizations in responding to the climate crisis through the lens of health. The event was held in collaboration with the Jameel Arts Health Lab, a joint effort between Jameel Arts Centre, Nadia Christidi, Uns Kattan, and Dr. Marina Romanello. 

Nadia Christidi, a researcher, writer, and arts practitioner, is currently a PhD candidate in History, Anthropology, and Science, Technology, and Society at MIT. She has a particular interest in how art, design, and architecture can be utilized in future imagining and planning processes. 

Uns Kattan, the deputy director and head of research and learning at Art Jameel, has a strong interest in visual culture and alternative histories. For over ten years, she has worked in various capacities including research, programming, and content development. 

Dr. Marina Romanello, the executive director of the Lancet Countdown and a health researcher at University College London, has a background in clinical biochemistry and biomedical sciences. She is also a member of the working group on health co-benefits in climate change mitigation policies for Italy’s Superior Health Council. 

Dr. Nisha Sajnani, a founding co-director of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab, established in collaboration with the World Health Organization (WHO), New York University (NYU), Community Jameel, and Culturunners, works to improve health and wellbeing through the arts. She is also the director of the program in drama therapy and theatre & health lab, as well as a founding co-director of the Arts & Health @NYU. 

Stephen Stapleton, an artist, social entrepreneur, and founding director of CULTURUNNERS, is known for developing platforms for cultural exchange with the Middle East. He is also a founding co-director of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab, established in collaboration with the WHO, NYU, Community Jameel, and Culturunners. 

Cléa Daridan, the senior curator and cultural lead at Community Jameel, is also a senior lecturer at the École Nationale Supérieure des Arts Décoratifs in Paris. 

This series aims to amplify local communities and foster a more inclusive and informed discussion around climate action. It also seeks to build a forum for intergenerational collaboration and engagement, channeling a unique voice and inspiring thoughtful discussions between youth, experts, non-experts, and key global decision-makers. 

About Our Work: 

We at the Community Jameel x Afikra COP28 Conversations are dedicated to fostering a deeper appreciation for the Arab

FRANCE'S CIMCL NAMES 2025 WINNERS

The prestigious Concours International de Musique de Chambre de Lyon (CIMCL) has announced its winners for the year 2025. This year marked the competition's 20th edition, and it focused on the voice-piano duo.

CIMCL, held annually, is known for highlighting different types of chamber music ensembles, such as piano trios, violin-piano duos, and string quartets. The talented musicians compete for various prizes, including the first prize of €8,000, second prize of €6,000, and third prize of €4,000.

Among the winners, Berlin's Duo Vert stood out, comprising bass-baritone Jeeyoung Lim and pianist Cole Knutson. The duo was awarded the first prize of €8,000. London-based Duo Nuvoletta, formed by soprano Clara Barbier Serrano and pianist Joanna Kacperek, won the second prize of €6,000 as well as the Audience Award. They also received the Belle Saison Prize and the Public Prize.

The third prize of €4,000 went to Paris-Tokyo group Duo Musubi, featuring soprano Yui Nanasawa and pianist Kishin Nagai. They also received the €1,000 Prize for Best Performance of Jean-Patrick Besingrand's "Chants du Déversoir." Additionally, the €1,000 SEAM Prize for Commitment to Contemporary Music was awarded to Duo Autekia, formed by tenor Abel Zamora and pianist Félix Moussiegt. The Villecroze Academy Prize was given to soprano Clarisse Dalles and pianist Joseph Birnbaum of Duo Dalles-Birnbaum.

Apart from the cash prizes, CIMCL's Villecroze Academy and Belle Saison Prizes also offer performance opportunities at live events, a Belle Saison tour, entry to the Villecroze Music Academy, and concert engagements with the Royaumont Foundation, Palazzetto Bru Zane, and more.

The jury was made up of esteemed musicians, including Bernarda Fink, Chantal Santon-Jeffery, Markus Hadulla, Mark Padmore, Susan Manoff, and Dietrich Henschel.

Founded in 2023, The Violin Channel is a New York City-based leading international classical music news, media, and streaming platform. With over 600,000+ followers on social media and an email subscription base of over 100,000, it reaches over 2 million readers every month. The platform provides comprehensive coverage of international classical music events, including news, industry updates, masterclasses, competition coverage, interviews, educational resources, events, and concert livestreams. It also focuses on promoting talented young string soloists and ensembles.

The Violin Channel has gained the trust of its 2 million+ monthly
